string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on quantitative data collection techniques. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

The objectives of today’s lecture are to understand:

• Measurement sensitivity

• Tests

• Questionnaires

• Interviews

• Observations

• Problems in measuring

Measurement sensitivity refers to the ability of a measure to identify and discriminate differences. We can’t show a relationship if the instrument doesn’t measure the constructs of interest very well.

For example, using minutes to record 50 yard swimming might not be the best way to differentiate athletes’ performance. Using seconds would provide a more precise measurement of each individual’s ability.

Oftentimes, how we ask questions will affect the results of a research. In this example of examining the relationship between self-efficacy and achievement. If you only pick high/low to measure self-efficacy and pass/fail to measure achievement, this is very insensitive because you would not be able to discriminate much for either variables.

The circle on the right side uses specific measures of self-efficacy that is related to the performance on a test in class. You then examine achievement as measured by the test, giving you a wide range of scores for both variables. You now have more sensitive data to work with. It’s more likely to find the relationship between the two variables.

To collect useful quantitative data, we need a measure that will provide a good distribution of scores - scores that will significantly differentiate one from another.

For example, instead of asking a simple yes/no question, ask a question that will measure in scale. Here instead of asking teachers if they use technology in the classroom or not, ask them how often they use technology in the classroom to get various degrees of usages.

This is one way to show measurement sensitivity. You can always do a pilot test with a few individuals to get a sense if a measure will give you a good distribution of scores. Looking into previous studies is also a good way to find validated instruments.

A test is a measure that requires individuals to complete a cognitive task by responding to a standard set of questions. Answers are summarized to obtain a numerical score. There are two different approaches to score interpretation: norm-referenced or criterion-referenced. The method does affect the interpretation of test results.

The purpose of a criterion-referenced (or standards-based) interpretation is to show how an individual’s performance compares to an established level of performance. The result is usually reported as pass, proficient, or advanced. Professional judgment is required to set the passing or mastery score. It does not compare student to student. The key is to make sure that students know certain concepts and have certain skills. Examples include grading scales such as 95-100 equals to A, 88 to 94 equals to B, and so on.

In norm-referenced interpretation, individual scores are compared with the scores of a well-defined norm (reference group) of others who have taken the same test. Ideally they would have at the same grade level and age group. Pay attention to the word normal, it is a way to compare one person’s performance to what is normal for other people like him or her. Examples include SAT, IQ test, or any test that offers a percentile is a norm-referenced test.

Now comes a term called z-score that you might have come across in reading quantitative research. Z-scores measure of how many standard deviations below or above the population mean a raw score is.

A z-score of 1 is one standard deviation above the mean. A z-score of 2 is two standard deviations above the mean. In case you are curious, to calculate a z-score, you subtract the mean from each score and divide it by the standard Deviation. What is z-score good for?

Let me use one example to put z-score in context. Say, Tom is a fourteen-year old whose height is about 5’1”. I used an online calculator to compare his height with teenagers of his age and learn that his z-score is -1.06. I can use this normal distribution curve graph here to determine the percentile. I am going to put a line right at a z-score of -1.06 which will give me roughly 14%. That means he is taller than 14% of teenagers of his age. Z-score can be very useful for ranking academic performance, business performance, health performance, and so on.

http://www.quesgen.com/BMIPedsCalc.php

Now let’s move on to one more method of quantitative data collection. A questionnaire is a written document containing prompts or questions that are used to obtain an individual’s perceptions, attitudes, beliefs, values, perspectives, and other traits. It is a very effective way to obtain information about a wide range of research problems, from survey of large population to reactions of students to different instructional methods.

There are different types of items used for designing questionnaires: scales, ranked items, and checklists.

A scale is a progressive series of gradations of something. Likert scale is the most widely used example. In a true Likert scale, the statement includes a value or positive or negative direction, and respondent indicates agreement or disagreement with the statement as shown in the first example here.

In a rank-ordered questionnaire, the respondent is asked to place a limited number of categories into sequential order. The sequence could be based on importance, liking, degree of experience, or some other dimension as shown in the second example. In this example, you are asked to use 1 as least important and 5 as very important to rank the importance of the subjects in school.

A checklist provides the respondent with a number of options from which to choose. The checklist can require a choice of one of several alternative as shown in the third example.

There are many excellent Internet tools for creating surveys and questionnaires. Here are a few popular tools such as Qualtrics, Google Sheets, Survey Monkey, PollEverywhere, or QuestionPro.

The benefits of Internet-based surveys could save money and time and they are equally reliable. These survey’s provide access to distant participants.

The disadvantages of Internet based survey’s are low response rate, concern for confidentiality might result in bias, and it’s not known who actually completed the survey

Interviews are also a very useful means of collecting quantitative data. The interview is a form of data collection in which questions are asked orally and participants’ responses are recorded, verbatim and/or summarized. Usually we will develop an interview protocol, essential a script, that includes the procedures, questions, and prompts.

There are three types of interview questions

-Structured questions are usually close-ended for participants to choose an answer from. For example, “how important is it for you to go to college? “The answer is chosen from “it is critical, very important, important, or not very important.” Structured questions are often used in phone interviews.

-Semi-structured questions can be used in both quantitative or qualitative studies. The questions are open-ended with specific intent. It allows for probing and clarification. For instance, an interviewer might ask, “What are some things at school that you like to do best?”

-Unstructured questions are open-ended and broad . The interviewers has a general goal in mind and asks questions relevant to this goal.

Regardless the type of question, interviewers need to avoid “leading the questions” by encouraging a specific answer from all participants. Also interviewers:

-Need to act as a neutral medium through which the information is transmitted

-Must be trained to avoid bias

We also need to consider:

-Demographic characteristics of the interviewer which may influence responses.

-The manner of recording responses may affect results.

All previously mentioned methods such as tests, questionnaires, and interviews rely on self-reports by the participants. They may have bias related to participant motivation or response set. Observation technique does not rely on self-reports and will generate more first-hand data.

Some observations are made in natural settings and others in more controlled settings. Observational data could support both quantitative and qualitative research. Quantitative observations rely on numbers to summarize what has been observed. Here are two observational forms. The top one is a generic form to observe student on-task behaviors before and after interventions.

The bottom one is to record if students with autism spectrum disorder can perform target behaviors after watching video modeling on how to take the school bus. This observation form can be used to collect data from baseline (before), intervention (during), and maintenances (after) phases on a daily basis.

There are three observer effects that are potential limitations of the observation method.

Observer bias

-Bias can be both positive or negative.

-If an observer prefers a certain way of classroom management technique, the observer may give positive ratings toward a classroom that is more aligned with the observer’s pre-determined preference.

Contamination

-Contamination occurs when the observer has knowledge of one or more aspects of the study and the knowledge affects subsequent observations. For example, if an observer knows which groups is “expected” to do best, he or she may unconsciously favor that group.

Halo effect

-Halo effect occurs when observer allows an initial impression of a person or group to influence subsequent observations. For example, an initial impression of a teacher, based on how the teacher starts a class, may create a positive impression about the teacher. This may create an overall positive “halo” so this teacher might receive favorable ratings in the observation. The Halo effect can be reduced with proper training.

Compared with cognitive measures, such as achievement and aptitude tests, noncognitive instruments such as questionnaire, interviews and observation generally have lower reliability and less evidence for validity. Here’s a quick overview of commonly occurred problems under each type of instrument.

When using questionnaire, response set is the tendency of the participant to respond in the same way, regardless of the content of the items, for example, always selecting the neutral category in a Likert scale. Faking occurs when participants give deliberately inaccurate indications of their attitudes, personality, or interests. Participants may fake the results to please the researchers. Review this list and be aware of these problems when evaluating the quality of measurement.

In this video, we have review different ways to collect quantitative data, including

• Tests

• Questionnaires

• Interviews

• Observations.

We also discussed

• Measurement sensitivity

• Problems in measuring
